defs.docs: Winit allows you to build a window on as many platforms as possible.

attributes.value: / Winit allows you to build a window on as many platforms as possible.
/ # Building a window
/ Before you can build a window, you first need to build an `EventsLoop`. This is done with the
/ `EventsLoop::new()` function. Example:
/ ```no_run
/ use winit::EventsLoop;
/ let events_loop = EventsLoop::new();
/ Once this is done there are two ways to create a window:
/  - Calling `Window::new(&events_loop)`.
/  - Calling `let builder = WindowBuilder::new()` then `builder.build(&events_loop)`.
/ The first way is the simpliest way and will give you default values for everything.
/ The second way allows you to customize the way your window will look and behave by modifying
/ the fields of the `WindowBuilder` object before you create the window.
/ # Events handling
/ Once a window has been created, it will *generate events*. For example whenever the user moves
/ the window, resizes the window, moves the mouse, etc. an event is generated.
/ The events generated by a window can be retreived from the `EventsLoop` the window was created
/ with.
/ There are two ways to do so. The first is to call `events_loop.poll_events(...)`, which will
/ retreive all the events pending on the windows and immediately return after no new event is
/ available. You usually want to use this method in application that render continuously on the
/ screen, such as video games.
/ ```no_run
/ use winit::{Event, WindowEvent};
/ # use winit::EventsLoop;
/ # let mut events_loop = EventsLoop::new();
/ loop {
/     events_loop.poll_events(|event| {
/         match event {
/             Event::WindowEvent { event: WindowEvent::Resized(w, h), .. } => {
/                 println!("The window was resized to {}x{}", w, h);
/ The second way is to call `events_loop.run_forever(...)`. As its name tells, it will run
/ forever unless it is stopped by returning `ControlFlow::Break`.
/ ```no_run
/ use winit::{ControlFlow, Event, WindowEvent};
/ # use winit::EventsLoop;
/ # let mut events_loop = EventsLoop::new();
/ events_loop.run_forever(|event| {
/     match event {
/         Event::WindowEvent { event: WindowEvent::Closed, .. } => {
/             println!("The window was closed ; stopping");
/             ControlFlow::Break
/         _ => ControlFlow::Continue,
/ If you use multiple windows, the `WindowEvent` event has a member named `window_id`. You can
/ compare it with the value returned by the `id()` method of `Window` in order to know which
/ window has received the event.
/ # Drawing on the window
/ Winit doesn't provide any function that allows drawing on a window. However it allows you to
/ retreive the raw handle of the window (see the `os` module for that), which in turn allows you
/ to create an OpenGL/Vulkan/DirectX/Metal/etc. context that will draw on the window.

/ At the moment, only supported on Apple forcetouch-capable macbooks.
/ The parameters are: pressure level (value between 0 and 1 representing how hard the touchpad
/ is being pressed) and stage (integer representing the click level).

defs.name: HiDPIFactorChanged
defs.docs: DPI scaling factor of the window has changed.

attributes.value: / DPI scaling factor of the window has changed.
/ The following actions cause DPI changes:
/ * A user changes the resolution.
/ * A user changes the desktop scaling value (e.g. in Control Panel on Windows).
/ * A user moves the application window to a display with a different DPI.

defs.name: Motion
defs.docs:
Motion on some analog axis.  This event will be reported for all arbitrary input devices
 that winit supports on this platform, including mouse devices.  If the device is a mouse
 device then this will be reported alongside the MouseMotion event.

attributes.value: / Motion on some analog axis.  This event will be reported for all arbitrary input devices
/ that winit supports on this platform, including mouse devices.  If the device is a mouse
/ device then this will be reported alongside the MouseMotion event.

defs.name: DeviceEvent
defs.docs: Represents raw hardware events that are not associated with any particular window.

attributes.value: / Represents raw hardware events that are not associated with any particular window.
/ Useful for interactions that diverge significantly from a conventional 2D GUI, such as 3D camera or first-person
/ game controls. Many physical actions, such as mouse movement, can produce both device and window events. Because
/ window events typically arise from virtual devices (corresponding to GUI cursors and keyboard focus) the device IDs
/ may not match.
/ Note that these events are delivered regardless of input focus.

defs.name: KeyboardInput
defs.docs: Describes a keyboard input event.

attributes.value: / Describes a keyboard input event.

defs.name: scancode
defs.docs: Identifies the physical key pressed

attributes.value: / Identifies the physical key pressed
/ This should not change if the user adjusts the host's keyboard map. Use when the physical location of the
/ key is more important than the key's host GUI semantics, such as for movement controls in a first-person
/ game.

defs.name: virtual_keycode
defs.docs: Identifies the semantic meaning of the key

attributes.value: / Identifies the semantic meaning of the key
/ Use when the semantics of the key are more important than the physical location of the key, such as when
/ implementing appropriate behavior for "page up."

defs.name: modifiers
defs.docs: Modifier keys active at the time of this input.

attributes.value: / Modifier keys active at the time of this input.
/ This is tracked internally to avoid tracking errors arising from modifier key state changes when events from
/ this device are not being delivered to the application, e.g. due to keyboard focus being elsewhere.

defs.name: TouchPhase
defs.value: pub enum TouchPhase { Started, Moved, Ended, Cancelled, }
defs.docs: Describes touch-screen input state.

attributes.value: / Describes touch-screen input state.

defs.name: Touch
defs.docs: Represents touch event

attributes.value: / Represents touch event
/ Every time user touches screen new Start event with some finger id is generated.
/ When the finger is removed from the screen End event with same id is generated.
/ For every id there will be at least 2 events with phases Start and End (or Cancelled).
/ There may be 0 or more Move events.
/ Depending on platform implementation id may or may not be reused by system after End event.
/ Gesture regonizer using this event should assume that Start event received with same id
/ as previously received End event is a new finger and has nothing to do with an old one.
/ Touch may be cancelled if for example window lost focus.

defs.name: id
defs.docs: unique identifier of a finger.

attributes.value: / unique identifier of a finger.

defs.name: LineDelta
defs.docs:
Amount in lines or rows to scroll in the horizontal
 and vertical directions.

attributes.value: / Amount in lines or rows to scroll in the horizontal
/ and vertical directions.
/ Positive values indicate movement forward
/ (away from the user) or rightwards.

defs.name: PixelDelta
defs.docs:
Amount in pixels to scroll in the horizontal and
 vertical direction.

attributes.value: / Amount in pixels to scroll in the horizontal and
/ vertical direction.
/ Scroll events are expressed as a PixelDelta if
/ supported by the device (eg. a touchpad) and
/ platform.

/ This function is equivalent to `WindowBuilder::new().build(events_loop)`.
/ Error should be very rare and only occur in case of permission denied, incompatible system,
/  out of memory, etc.
inline

defs.name: set_title
defs.docs: Modifies the title of the window.

attributes.value: / Modifies the title of the window.
/ This is a no-op if the window has already been closed.
inline

defs.name: show
defs.docs: Shows the window if it was hidden.

attributes.value: / Shows the window if it was hidden.
/ ## Platform-specific
/ - Has no effect on Android
inline

defs.name: hide
defs.docs: Hides the window if it was visible.

attributes.value: / Hides the window if it was visible.

/ - Has no effect on Android

defs.name: get_position
defs.docs:
Returns the position of the top-left hand corner of the window relative to the
  top-left hand corner of the desktop.

attributes.value: / Returns the position of the top-left hand corner of the window relative to the
/  top-left hand corner of the desktop.
/ Note that the top-left hand corner of the desktop is not necessarily the same as
/  the screen. If the user uses a desktop with multiple monitors, the top-left hand corner
/  of the desktop is the top-left hand corner of the monitor at the top-left of the desktop.
/ The coordinates can be negative if the top-left hand corner of the window is outside
/  of the visible screen region.
/ Returns `None` if the window no longer exists.
inline

defs.name: set_position
defs.docs: Modifies the position of the window.

attributes.value: / Modifies the position of the window.
/ See `get_position` for more information about the coordinates.
/ This is a no-op if the window has already been closed.
inline

defs.name: get_inner_size
defs.docs: Returns the size in pixels of the client area of the window.

attributes.value: / Returns the size in pixels of the client area of the window.
/ The client area is the content of the window, excluding the title bar and borders.
/ These are the dimensions that need to be supplied to `glViewport`.
/ Returns `None` if the window no longer exists.
inline

defs.name: get_inner_size_points
defs.docs: Returns the size in points of the client area of the window.

attributes.value: / Returns the size in points of the client area of the window.
/ The client area is the content of the window, excluding the title bar and borders.
/ To get the dimensions of the frame buffer when calling `glViewport`, multiply with hidpi factor.
/ Returns `None` if the window no longer exists.
/ DEPRECATED
inline
deprecated

defs.name: get_inner_size_pixels
defs.docs: Returns the size in pixels of the client area of the window.

attributes.value: / Returns the size in pixels of the client area of the window.
/ The client area is the content of the window, excluding the title bar and borders.
/ These are the dimensions of the frame buffer, and the dimensions that you should use
/  when you call `glViewport`.
/ Returns `None` if the window no longer exists.
/ DEPRECATED
inline
deprecated

defs.name: get_outer_size
defs.docs: Returns the size in pixels of the window.

attributes.value: / Returns the size in pixels of the window.
/ These dimensions include title bar and borders. If you don't want these, you should use
/  use `get_inner_size` instead.
/ Returns `None` if the window no longer exists.
inline

defs.name: set_inner_size
defs.docs: Modifies the inner size of the window.

attributes.value: / Modifies the inner size of the window.
/ See `get_inner_size` for more information about the values.
/ This is a no-op if the window has already been closed.
inline

 window size in screen pixels. This is typically one for a normal display
 and two for a retina display.

defs.name: os
defs.docs: Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.

attributes.value: / Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.
/ Contains the follow modules:
/  - `android`
/  - `macos`
/  - `unix`
/  - `windows`
/ However only the module corresponding to the platform you're compiling to will be available.

cfg(any(target_os = "linux", target_os = "dragonfly", target_os = "freebsd",
          target_os = "openbsd"))

defs.name: Window
defs.docs: Represents a window.

attributes.value: / Represents a window.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ use winit::{Event, EventsLoop, Window, WindowEvent, ControlFlow};
/ let mut events_loop = EventsLoop::new();
/ let window = Window::new(&events_loop).unwrap();
/ events_loop.run_forever(|event| {
/     match event {
/         Event::WindowEvent { event: WindowEvent::Closed, .. } => {
/             ControlFlow::Break
/         _ => ControlFlow::Continue,

defs.name: WindowId
defs.docs: Identifier of a window. Unique for each window.

attributes.value: / Identifier of a window. Unique for each window.
/ Can be obtained with `window.id()`.
/ Whenever you receive an event specific to a window, this event contains a `WindowId` which you
/ can then compare to the ids of your windows.

defs.name: DeviceId
defs.docs: Identifier of an input device.

attributes.value: / Identifier of an input device.
/ Whenever you receive an event arising from a particular input device, this event contains a `DeviceId` which
/ identifies its origin. Note that devices may be virtual (representing an on-screen cursor and keyboard focus) or
/ physical. Virtual devices typically aggregate inputs from multiple physical devices.

defs.name: EventsLoop
defs.docs:
Provides a way to retreive events from the system and from the windows that were registered to
 the events loop.

attributes.value: / Provides a way to retreive events from the system and from the windows that were registered to
/ the events loop.
/ An `EventsLoop` can be seen more or less as a "context". Calling `EventsLoop::new()`
/ initializes everything that will be required to create windows. For example on Linux creating
/ an events loop opens a connection to the X or Wayland server.
/ To wake up an `EventsLoop` from a another thread, see the `EventsLoopProxy` docs.
/ Note that the `EventsLoop` cannot be shared accross threads (due to platform-dependant logic
/ forbiding it), as such it is neither `Send` nor `Sync`. If you need cross-thread access, the
/ `Window` created from this `EventsLoop` _can_ be sent to an other thread, and the
/ `EventsLoopProxy` allows you to wakeup an `EventsLoop` from an other thread.

defs.name: Continue
defs.docs: Continue looping and waiting for events.

attributes.value: / Continue looping and waiting for events.

defs.name: Break
defs.docs: Break from the event loop.

attributes.value: / Break from the event loop.

defs.name: ControlFlow
defs.docs: Returned by the user callback given to the `EventsLoop::run_forever` method.

attributes.value: / Returned by the user callback given to the `EventsLoop::run_forever` method.
/ Indicates whether the `run_forever` method should continue or complete.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Builds a new events loop.

attributes.value: / Builds a new events loop.
/ Usage will result in display backend initialisation, this can be controlled on linux
/ using an environment variable `WINIT_UNIX_BACKEND`. Legal values are `x11` and `wayland`.
/ If it is not set, winit will try to connect to a wayland connection, and if it fails will
/ fallback on x11. If this variable is set with any other value, winit will panic.

defs.name: poll_events
defs.value: pub fn poll_events<F>(&mut Self, F) where F: FnMut(Event) -> ()
defs.docs:
Fetches all the events that are pending, calls the callback function for each of them,
 and returns.

attributes.value: / Fetches all the events that are pending, calls the callback function for each of them,
/ and returns.
inline

defs.name: run_forever
defs.value: pub fn run_forever<F>(&mut Self, F) where F: FnMut(Event) -> ControlFlow
defs.docs:
Calls `callback` every time an event is received. If no event is available, sleeps the
 current thread and waits for an event. If the callback returns `ControlFlow::Break` then
 `run_forever` will immediately return.

attributes.value: / Calls `callback` every time an event is received. If no event is available, sleeps the
/ current thread and waits for an event. If the callback returns `ControlFlow::Break` then
/ `run_forever` will immediately return.
inline

Creates an `EventsLoopProxy` that can be used to wake up the `EventsLoop` from another
 thread.

attributes.value: / Creates an `EventsLoopProxy` that can be used to wake up the `EventsLoop` from another
/ thread.

defs.name: EventsLoopProxy
defs.docs: Used to wake up the `EventsLoop` from another thread.

attributes.value: / Used to wake up the `EventsLoop` from another thread.

defs.name: wakeup
defs.docs: Wake up the `EventsLoop` from which this proxy was created.

attributes.value: / Wake up the `EventsLoop` from which this proxy was created.
/ This causes the `EventsLoop` to emit an `Awakened` event.
/ Returns an `Err` if the associated `EventsLoop` no longer exists.

defs.name: EventsLoopClosed
defs.docs:
The error that is returned when an `EventsLoopProxy` attempts to wake up an `EventsLoop` that
 no longer exists.

attributes.value: / The error that is returned when an `EventsLoopProxy` attempts to wake up an `EventsLoop` that
/ no longer exists.

defs.name: Progress
defs.docs:
Progress indicator. Shows that processing is being done. But in contrast
 with "Wait" the user may still interact with the program. Often rendered
 as a spinning beach ball, or an arrow with a watch or hourglass.

attributes.value: / Progress indicator. Shows that processing is being done. But in contrast

Indicate that some edge is to be moved. For example, the 'SeResize' cursor
 is used when the movement starts from the south-east corner of the box.

defs.name: MouseCursor
defs.value:
pub enum MouseCursor {
    Default,
    Crosshair,
    Hand,
    Arrow,
    Move,
    Text,
    Wait,
    Help,
    Progress,
    NotAllowed,
    ContextMenu,
    NoneCursor,
    Cell,
    VerticalText,
    Alias,
    Copy,
    NoDrop,
    Grab,
    Grabbing,
    AllScroll,
    ZoomIn,
    ZoomOut,
    EResize,
    NResize,
    NeResize,
    NwResize,
    SResize,
    SeResize,
    SwResize,
    WResize,
    EwResize,
    NsResize,
    NeswResize,
    NwseResize,
    ColResize,
    RowResize,
}
defs.docs: Describes the appearance of the mouse cursor.

attributes.value: / Describes the appearance of the mouse cursor.

defs.name: Normal

attributes.value: / Normal cursor behavior.

defs.name: Hide
defs.docs: The cursor will be invisible when over the window.

attributes.value: / The cursor will be invisible when over the window.

defs.name: Grab
defs.docs:
Grabs the mouse cursor. The cursor's motion will be confined to this
 window and the window has exclusive access to further events regarding
 the cursor.

attributes.value: / Grabs the mouse cursor. The cursor's motion will be confined to this
/ window and the window has exclusive access to further events regarding
/ the cursor.
/ This is useful for first-person cameras for example.

defs.value: pub enum CursorState { Normal, Hide, Grab, }
defs.docs: Describes how winit handles the cursor.

attributes.value: / Describes how winit handles the cursor.

defs.name: WindowAttributes
defs.value: WindowAttributes { dimensions, min_dimensions, max_dimensions, fullscreen, title, maximized, visible, transparent, decorations, multitouch }
defs.docs: Attributes to use when creating a window.

attributes.value: / Attributes to use when creating a window.

defs.name: dimensions
defs.docs:
The dimensions of the window. If this is `None`, some platform-specific dimensions will be
 used.

attributes.value: / The dimensions of the window. If this is `None`, some platform-specific dimensions will be
/ used.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: min_dimensions
defs.docs: The minimum dimensions a window can be, If this is `None`, the window will have no minimum dimensions (aside from reserved).

attributes.value: / The minimum dimensions a window can be, If this is `None`, the window will have no minimum dimensions (aside from reserved).
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: max_dimensions
defs.docs: The maximum dimensions a window can be, If this is `None`, the maximum will have no maximum or will be set to the primary monitor's dimensions by the platform.

attributes.value: / The maximum dimensions a window can be, If this is `None`, the maximum will have no maximum or will be set to the primary monitor's dimensions by the platform.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: fullscreen
defs.docs: Whether the window should be set as fullscreen upon creation.

attributes.value: / Whether the window should be set as fullscreen upon creation.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: title
defs.docs: The title of the window in the title bar.

attributes.value: / The title of the window in the title bar.
/ The default is `"winit window"`.

defs.name: maximized
defs.docs: Whether the window should be maximized upon creation.

attributes.value: / Whether the window should be maximized upon creation.
/ The default is `false`.

defs.name: visible
defs.docs: Whether the window should be immediately visible upon creation.

attributes.value: / Whether the window should be immediately visible upon creation.
/ The default is `true`.

defs.name: transparent
defs.docs:
Whether the the window should be transparent. If this is true, writing colors
 with alpha values different than `1.0` will produce a transparent window.

attributes.value: / Whether the the window should be transparent. If this is true, writing colors
/ with alpha values different than `1.0` will produce a transparent window.
/ The default is `false`.

defs.name: decorations
defs.docs: Whether the window should have borders and bars.

attributes.value: / Whether the window should have borders and bars.
/ The default is `true`.

[iOS only] Enable multitouch,
 see [multipleTouchEnabled](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiview/1622519-multipletouchenabled)

attributes.value: / [iOS only] Enable multitouch,
